channel.title: "Reflection Agent" thingo
channel.description:
hi. This is my erhmm... bot. Basically it just uses [b]Instrumentation.getAllLoadedClasses[/b] so we can obtain all of the clients classes and then use reflection on them. It is just a shitty "quick'n'easy" bot. Have fun!!! :cool:
ps. remember to use "makelink"!!! You can use the "Test" script to find the chat fields!!!

item.title: "Reflection Agent" thingo
item.dc:creator: @pplsuqbawlz pplsuqbawlz
item.description:
@pplsuqbawlz wrote:

[quote=“semaphore, post:28, topic:309992”][quote author=Unhandled link=topic=406415.msg3011503#msg3011503 date=1256815673]
I’ll admit, C wasn’t my first language, but I don’t see how you’ll ever learn much about OOP using C.
[/quote]

Surprisingly many people know java but still have yet to learn much about OOP.

But, OOP is just a methodology; just like procedural programming is. It has its place. It’s definitely not the silver bullet solution for everything.[/quote]

Where do abstract languages fit in your world mate? I blame the Christians.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @qauters qauters
item.description:
@qauters wrote:

VB.net --> VC++.net --> Java --> C#.net --> c++
Going from java to c++ is easier, since you keep the OOP although you have to learn about memory management etc.
I know how to write such app, but that’s because I had to try different methods for QBot.

item.title: "Reflection Agent" thingo
item.dc:creator: @semaphore semaphore
item.description:
@semaphore wrote:

You’re right. Learning c just to screw around with JVMTI will leave you confused and frustrated.

You should learn c to better understand the ultimate foundation of java. There’s an old quote that resurfaces every now and again at the client sites I work with. It seems that there’s a generation of coders whose first language is java. This is somewhat troubling because of just how much one misses by only learning java.

Anyway here is the quote:

If you know c, java is simple.
If you only know java, good luck with c.

I’m sure there are exceptions to the rule but I’ve worked with hundreds of developers. I’ve never found an exception. The only people that have ever disagreed with me on this are those that learned java first. I’ve even had people that learned java first say ‘Oh I had no problem learning c!’, but when given a task… say… create a small app that reads from shared memory and forks a new process on write to the memory and notifies the parent process by writing to a predefined shared block of memory… deer in headlights. In fact most of them don’t even know how to fork a new process.

If you learned C first, you would agree with me that java is morbidly simple in comparison. (TBH I look at java in much the same way most java developers look at javascript).

Read full topic

item.title: "Reflection Agent" thingo
item.dc:creator: @White_Castle White Castle
item.description:
@White_Castle wrote:

When you request events with JDI, you can specify whether or not it blocks the entire JVM (SUSPEND_ALL), the relevant thread (SUSPEND_EVENT_THREAD), or nothing at all (SUSPEND_NONE). It queues automatically for you (there’s no other way to receive an event; “There is one instance of EventQueue assigned to a particular VirtualMachine.”). So, I suspect the slowness is simply due to JDI being an abstraction of JVMTI. JNI is not very fast, from what I’ve heard.

I’m not gonna learn C just to screw around with JVMTI :/.

Read full topic

item.title: "Reflection Agent" thingo
item.dc:creator: @Jython super_
item.description:
@Jython wrote:

White Castle:

I was never advocating taking the JDI approach. Reflection is slow, but adding field modification/access listeners slows the JVM down to the point of not being able to run RS (method entry/exit listeners are even worse). I was simply mentioning that you don’t have to resort to native agents to get more power than instrumentation has.

they aren’t if you only set them on needed fields and queue the modification info rather than handle it immediately and block the vm

Read full topic

item.title: "Reflection Agent" thingo
item.dc:creator: @BAsh BAsh
item.description:
@BAsh wrote:

Want to record field modification? Use Instrumentation to redefine all the classes to call your method or however you want to implement it. Costs: the time it takes to loop through all classes. If the client has been running for a while some bits would have been JIT compiled and that would have to be redone. After 5secs or so the client should be running at the speed it was before the hooking. Only difference is the call to your method which should be very quick, too quick to notice.

There is no point using native when you can do something like this.

Read full topic

item.title: "Reflection Agent" thingo
item.dc:creator: @White_Castle White Castle
item.description:
@White_Castle wrote:

I was never advocating taking the JDI approach. Reflection is slow, but adding field modification/access listeners slows the JVM down to the point of not being able to run RS (method entry/exit listeners are even worse). I was simply mentioning that you don’t have to resort to native agents to get more power than instrumentation has.

Read full topic

item.title: "Reflection Agent" thingo
item.dc:creator: @Jython super_
item.description:
@Jython wrote:

[quote=“White Castle, post:17, topic:309992”][quote author=oksuper_ link=topic=406415.msg3008632#msg3008632 date=1256592483]

You can do things like that with Java too: JDI. Although I’m having a hard time making it not slow as balls.

research what you talk about… there are certain capabilities that can only be set before the vm has started, which is something that JAVA CODE THAT IS BEING INTERPRETED can certainly not do.
[/quote]

Erm, there’s a two-JVM thing going on with JDI. The observing JVM can start either before or after the observed JVM. You big fat grump.[/quote]

if you’re going to run it locally, then why even take the jdi approach?

Read full topic

item.title: "Reflection Agent" thingo
item.dc:creator: @Jython super_
item.description:
@Jython wrote:

[quote=“Mopman, post:12, topic:309992”][quote author=marluxia link=topic=406415.msg3004521#msg3004521 date=1256268459]Also, wat da fuk is a native agent .
[/quote]

Java agents don’t have to be written in Java, they can be native code. Not sure how that makes them more powerful, though :/[/quote]

because they can directly manipulate low-level settings etc. before the VM is even started… something you can’t do with javaagents. tip: field access and modification hooks anyone?

Read full topic

item.description:
@marluxia wrote:

[quote=“oksuper_, post:10, topic:309992”]you should at the least give credit to:
http://www.craigethomas.com/blog/2009/01/java-applet-instrumentation/[/quote]

ahhh yes. I was hoping that someone would also pick-up that “script.java” looks suspiciously like something out of arga (also the tabs) =P. Also, wat da fuk is a native agent .

Tenen:

what’s the point of obtaining and using the applet panel cache when all the needed fields are static and don’t need an instance?

to send events to the applet. Actually this is done rather dodgily but the bot was just meant for a piss around.

@OP: are you going any further with this?

I might work on it a bit more if I have time.
